Author: BigBulkemails

Comment Text:
The only reason I know what is going on is because I have family in the country, and my wife and I are closely monitoring the situation because of how it affects us. 

But a good chunk of the world has no idea. 

Unlike the protests in Hong Kong, or even Thailand, what worries me the most is how this most likely wonâ€™t catch the hearts and minds of western media. 

Myanmar has an opportunity to be something great, but the protestors need to do something attractive to make the west want to listen and root for the people. 

I hate to say it, but Myanmar doesnâ€™t have much going for itself at the moment that would immediately want westerns to flock towards supporting a protest that, if successful, could radically change the country for the better. Myanmar isnâ€™t a top tourist destination like Thailand, and it isnâ€™t a global financial center like Hong Kong. Instead, itâ€™s a country that many people havenâ€™t heard of, and those who have, know very little about. 

Iâ€™m not saying this stuff to belittle the protests, but instead, Iâ€™m saying this because I believe this generation needs to think outside the box, get the world to understand what is going on and what you are fighting for. 

The majority of the comments I keep seeing from those westerns who like to think theyâ€™re â€˜wokeâ€™ is that ASSK deserves this. While most people subscribed to this sub clearly recognize how that is anything but true, it is important to remember that the media spent the last three years dragging her through the mud, instead of reporting on both sides. 

Either way, this isnâ€™t really about ASSK, rather, the NLD, what it means, and what Myanmar has to gain. Tell that story to the world. Make them want to listen, and regain the sympathy that the Burmese, and the millions of ethnic minorities living within your boarders deserve.

Comment Text:
I will respond to you the final time, even though I am not sure if you will engage in me with good faith. I like to believe in people.

>In response to the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army attack thousands of people were killed, women raped, and children were being decapitated. 700,000 people were left as refugees. How can you justify that?

I don't justify that. You never justify genocide. What happened to the Rohingya people was horrible and there is nothing really people can do now to atone that other than to stop the oppressions against them and put on the trial the people responsible for the genocide ( even DASSK).

Now this is something no one can do with the military government in power. With a democracy instituted, we can at least have the chance of a political party coming in to reign ( after the NLD) that will acknowledge the genocide of the Rohingyas.

>All of you are saying the military is in charge in response to everything Iâ€™ve been saying. Well, theyâ€™re in charge NOW and people donâ€™t seem afraid of protesting. So what was stopping you from protesting the Rohingya genocide?

Yes, there were very few to no protests for the genocide of the Rohingya people.[Any journalists who reported on it were jailed](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-48182712)and any emotions of sympathy for them were shunned.

What was stopping you( the majority of Myanmar I'm assuming unless you can somehow read my mind) from protesting? Rising racial tensions and animosity towards the Rohingya seeded from military propaganda. Although I am sure that there were some xenophobic sentiments prior to the propaganda, [however the propaganda did make it more rampant and successfully influenced the majority of the Burmese people. (boycott facebook)](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/15/technology/myanmar-facebook-genocide.html)

This is not an excuse however to our complicity to the genocide. We were complicit, that is true. There is no atonement to genocide.

[I believe and hope that during this coup, it is the opportune time for us to start realizing and acknowledging the struggles of the Rohingya people. Some Rohingya activists agree too.](https://time.com/5936604/myanmar-coup-rohingya/)

I am hoping that I am not replying to someone who thinks that the whole population of Myanmar deserves this just for their complicity. Or even worse, to die for their complicity. Fighting racism against racism isn't particularly smart.

The reason why I take issue with the sentiment of "Good they deserve this, I hope the Military fuck them all over like they did the Rohingyas", it is the irony and failure to recognize that the Rohingyas will STILL be persecuted and most probably worse under Military rule. The invoking of the genocide in that sentiment feels insincere and honestly seems just like a cover to parade their sadism and "virtue" . I doubt that people who truly care for the Rohingyas are happy that the military is taking over.

I hope you understand  the points I've made. I hope you respond back (if you do) with the intention to understand or to be understood rather than just to respond. I hope a lot.

Enjoy your day.
Author: XaniteBlank
